dict.string: Allows users to resume printers or print jobs without being an administrator.

#!/bin/bash
# Exit 0 means not installed # Exit 1 means installed
# See if the cupsd.conf file contains the word "Resume-" testValue=$(grep "Resume-" /etc/cups/cupsd.conf)
# See if the value is empty if [ -z $testValue ]; then exit 1 else exit 0 fi

#!/bin/bash
# First, temporarily disable the CUPS service sudo launchctl unload -w /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/org.cups.cupsd.plist
# Back up the file with the current timestamp, and do a find/replace "Resume-Printer " and "Resume-Job " #sudo sed -i.bak$(date +%Y%m%d%H%M%S) -e s/"Resume-Job "/""/g -e s/"Resume-Printer "/""/g /etc/cups/cupsd.conf sudo sed -i.AllowResumebak -e s/"Resume-Job "/""/g -e s/"Resume-Printer "/""/g /etc/cups/cupsd.conf
# Re-enable the CUPS service sudo launchctl load -w /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/org.cups.cupsd.plist

#!/bin/bash
# First, temporarily disable the CUPS service sudo launchctl unload -w /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/org.cups.cupsd.plist
# Double-check the backup exists if [ -f /etc/cups/cupsd.conf.AllowResumebak ] && [ -f /etc/cups/cupsd.conf ]; then
# Delete the current sudo rm /etc/cups/cupsd.conf
# Rename the backup sudo mv /etc/cups/cupsd.conf.AllowResumebak /etc/cups/cupsd.conf
fi
# Re-enable the CUPS service sudo launchctl load -w /System/Library/LaunchDaemons/org.cups.cupsd.plist
